urn:contentItem:6GTM-9433-RW7V-B3VX-00000-00Avadel Pharmaceuticals plc (AVDL )FY 2024 Conference Call Transcript2024-03-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:49ZLexisNexisAvadel Pharmaceuticals plc (AVDL )FY 2024 Conference Call TranscriptCall Participants:

Gregory J. Divis -- Chief Executive Officer & Director (Avadel Pharmaceuticals plc)

Richard Kim -- Chief Commercial Officer (Avadel Pharmaceuticals plc)

Thomas S. McHugh -- Chief Financial Officer (Avadel Pharmaceuticals plc)

Marc Goodman -- Analyst (SVB Leerink)


Presentation

Marc Goodman:

All right, welcome back to another session. I'm Marc Goodman, one of the biotech analysts at Leerink, and we're very happy to have Avadel Pharmaceuticals here. And we have Greg, the CEO; Richard Kim, who's the Chief Commercial Officer; and everybody knows Tom as well, who's the CFO. Thank you so much for joining us. Obviously an exciting time, products doing well, getting off, certainly totally different from the last year, two years, whatever we've been talking about this.

Questions And Answers

Marc Goodman:

Maybe we can just start with just the broader oxybate market dynamics and just give us a sense of your sense of the broader market right now and what's happening, the growth dynamics?

Gregory J. Divis:

Sure. Thanks, Marc, for allowing us to be here. Even if we take a step broader in the narcolepsy market, we see from claims data about 170,000 patients who are prevalent care in the US. Prior to LUMRYZ coming to the marketplace, there was about 16,000 patients who are on the twice nightly first generation oxybates. And as we sort of try that now, unfortunately, now we have to piece together the data. Some data is no longer publicly available. We have to rely on claims for other sources here, so we probably can't give an exact numeric number of where the size of the marketplace is. But what we can say from the launch thus far is we have seen segments like the previously discontinued well represented, which have come back into the mix, and we've also seen a really good representation of new to oxybate patients. So our belief is the marketplace is growing. We still have to sort of maybe put together all the data from the different sources to sort of show exactly how much numerically it's grown.

Marc Goodman:

But is your sense that the market's growing 2% or 3%, something like that? I mean, is that general?

Gregory J. Divis:

Well, the overall marketplace for narcolepsy maybe, yes, for oxybates, because, for example, some of the segments have come back in probably at a rate greater than that early on, but it's really an exact number to it. But we've definitely sort of seen representation from all three of the patient segments we've talked about in the past. So we definitely sort of feel, and mostly hear from the service providers that there's more patients coming to the mix now. That's what it feels like.

Richard Kim:

I think the two things we know for sure is that patients who have come back in, who have previously been on an oxybate and had discontinued is a market growth. And we are seeing physicians treat patients who have right now and early in the launch.

Marc Goodman:

Right. So that's specifically for oxybate, too?

Richard Kim:

Specifically for oxybate.

Marc Goodman:

Yeah. Interesting. So what surprised you in the first six or so months of launch?

Richard Kim:

This is going to sound like one of those cliche answers. Not a lot really happened. For better or worse, we actually had a little more time to prepare for this launch. So we had done a lot of market research, we had used claims, we had spoken to providers, patients and the payers. So I wouldn't say nothing was surprising. We would say there was things that were maybe a little more difficult. Things like the fact that it's difficult to change people's behavior that's ingrained for 20 years. The fact that some people, despite sort of seeing identifying patients, they wouldn't want to rock the boat, per se, providers. But we've also started seeing tremendous advancement that we've made with this launch, sort of eight months into launch now as well.

So everything from getting almost 1,900 REMS certified GCPs to now over 2,200 patients in rise up who are showing an interest in using our product, that our fulfillment works. And we have over 1,200 patients who were initiated by the end of January, and the fact that we have over 80% of commercially covered lives where there's a LUMRYZ policy in place now. So we're super proud of what we've done. We have, as Greg likes to say, we have more wood to chop, but not surprises. But just maybe you can't always have a great assumption on when everything will occur in the marketplace and who adopts sooner versus who may adopt later as well.

Marc Goodman:

Any specific issues or anything you've had to deal with?

Richard Kim:

Maybe the biggest one that is probably true for almost any new product launch in a specialty field is product fulfillment. It's just a pain. It's just different. It's new. You're working through coverage here. So candidly, I think some of the people who put their first patients through early on in the launch may have had a different experience than the ones who are doing it more recently now as well. But we've also sort of seen as especially high volume users once they've gotten their first or second patient through, the velocity seems to be faster for their next patients to come through the system. And we're also clearly getting better at getting those patients onto LUMRYZ and started as well.

Gregory J. Divis:

We have a colleague, and Richard quotes this often, which in launches, you always see little mini campfires. You just don't want the forest fire. Right? We haven't seen the forest fire, and the team has done a great job and we feel like we've really built an incredibly strong foundation early on in a launch to continue to build and grow, as Richard noted, with a lot more wood the chop.

Marc Goodman:

Yeah. And fulfillment was like, how long did it take at the beginning versus now?

Richard Kim:

Especially at the beginning, Marc, they were almost all the scripts growing through medical necessity, which generally requires sort of medical necessity appeal, denial, that process. What we can see now is as our coverage has really increased to now, over 80% of commercially covered lives. If there's a policy that exists and you meet the prior authorization criteria, those patients are going through under a month. If there's a criteria, but they don't meet all the sort of PA, the steps that were required before you can go into an oxybate, which are same steps for any oxybate, there's usually a little bit of back and forth, so those are probably a little bit over a month. And those where there is no policy in place, those ones generally take the longest still. But that's our smallest segment that exists today.

Marc Goodman:

But even in a good scenario, it still takes a few weeks to get through this.

Richard Kim:

That's right. That's right.

Marc Goodman:

It just is.

Richard Kim:

Welcome to the United States, especially products.

Marc Goodman:

Right. Any anecdotal stories just about patients that you're hearing?

Richard Kim:

Well, many. And in fact, what's really cool is we're about to launch our LUMRYZ brand ambassadors. These are real patients on LUMRYZ who are going to start to share their stories online. But maybe one of the, I think back to a call I had with a sleep physician in December, give me some great feedback on many things. Also some things we can do better in some areas. But he's like, Richard, the one area I got to talk to you about is new to oxybate patients. He said in the past, it was a battle. It was like arm wrestling with these patients because they just couldn't get over the fact that I finally got diagnosed. I'm going to get on this therapy. I just told you I'm struggling with the night, and you're going to force me to wake up, he said that battle is gone now with LUMRYZ, it's gone. So it's a fundamentally different conversation for getting new patients to oxybates on.

So once again, we think about all of our segments. We have really good catalysts for all of them. But to me, that was represented because we know that from our past market research 40% to 50% of patients when offered a twice nightly oxybate, refuse to take it, with the biggest reason being because of the dosing regimen. So we believe that LUMRYZ can take a lot of that off the table now, going forward.

Marc Goodman:

Mind us, before the launch, where did you think the patients would come from? And here we are, six months in and are they coming from where you expected?

Richard Kim:

Yeah, I mean, we sort of stated that the majority of patients are switch patients with more coming from the mixed salt versus the twice nightly sodium oxybates. And obviously we're seeing good representation from previously discontinued and new to oxybates. It doesn't sort of surprise us where we are right now, because there were just numerically more patients who were on twice nightly oxybates. But the fact that we're getting really good representation from these previously discontinued, we think is awesome, because that one was like, are they really going to come back in and reengage? And the answer is heck yeah.

Marc Goodman:

Which means they stopped for the exact reason that you benefit.

Richard Kim:

That's right. I mean, Marc, it's funny, when you asked before what surprises, we were super thorough in our pre launch market research and our claims analysis and our audits, that we did. So once again, maybe a few smaller things, that surprises. But the fundamentals, not really at all.

Marc Goodman:

Yeah. And the patients are having good experiences and you're not hearing any issues. There's no side effect issue that's popped up that we weren't expecting because we know what, oxybates are.

Richard Kim:

Yeah, no, I think generally in line. I mean, is it perfect with every patient? The answer, of course, is no. But the vast majority of the feedback we receive has been very positive. And once again, especially from a patient perspective now to get those patient stories out there, and we sort of see that as a multiplier effect because the patient voice is very small at the beginning. Now, with over 1,200 patients who have initiated, more of those voices are out there to share their personal journeys as well. So we're just super excited to be in this next phase of our launch.

Marc Goodman:

And lastly, Xyrem versus Xywav, where are you getting more patients from?

Richard Kim:

We're getting more from Xywav. And you're giving me that look that some people give to me as well, because people with that, I would have maybe thought it would be the other way around. There's maybe three fundamental reasons for that. The first is today there are more patients on the mix salts than the twice nightly sodium oxybates. But about a year and a half into the Xywav launch, we did market research with patients and showed them the profile of LUMRYZ, and both groups were super-excited to learn about LUMRYZ and want to consider switching to LUMRYZ. But the Xywav patients barely eked out the Xyrem patients. And when we dug into the data, what we saw was the Xywav patients tended to be diagnosed for a shorter period of time. They switch treatment sooner. They are the early adopters, and I believe we've seen some of that as well.

But fundamentally, if you think about the impact of the salt, magnesium, calcium, potassium or sodium, it really doesn't do anything different to the narcolepsy outcome for the GHB. So we just believe with the unique proposition we have for LUMRYZ, it's attracted patients from every segment and any therapy that they've been on as well.

Marc Goodman:

What about any commentary on just discontinuation patients to just stop on your therapy?

Richard Kim:

Sure. I mean, we will have discontinuations like every other therapy, but when we look back at claims for the first generation oxybates, what the data will tell you is almost a quarter discontinue at 30 days and almost 50% at 12 months. And what we can sort of see is we look at similar milestones. We are meaningfully lower than those rates that the twice on the oxybates have shown us through claims data as well.

Marc Goodman:

And the patients you're losing after 30 days, I mean, these can't be switches. They must just be -- it's bizarre.

Richard Kim:

There's a little bit of everything. There's little things that we all get used to here as well. It could be insurance, it could be other things here. But let's face it, not any product gets 100% market share. There will people who may want to go back, and we've heard a couple of those cases, but what we can sort of say is the vast majority of patients have done very well and have stayed persistent on their LUMRYZ journey.

Marc Goodman:

So what's realistic for us to be thinking about as a kind of market penetration rate for you into the oxybate market? Do you think you're going to grab 20%, 30%, 40%? What do you think is realistic?

Richard Kim:

Thanks for asking me. Between my boss and our CFO right now, Marc. But no. When we did a ton of research before and during our launch, we did six different quant demand market research studies where LUMRYZ was given the highest market share in the oxybate category, between 40% and 61% over six different studies. And they also told us that the marketplace would grow because of LUMRYZ, of new starts, somewhere between 25% to 50%, with an average of 38%. And we have seen nothing that deters us now that we've been in the marketplace from the work that we did before launch and the research that we continue to do during launch as well. So we definitely sort of see why LUMRYZ should be the market leader in the oxybate field and have a very meaningful share going forward.

Marc Goodman:

So 50% is not crazy, not a forecast?

Richard Kim:

Well, it's what our market research shows consistently, six times.

Gregory J. Divis:

That's why we feel really great about the foundation we built. But that's why we say we have a lot more wooded job, because we're not there yet.

Marc Goodman:

Yeah. So let's talk about the 2024 sales. I think you mentioned on the call consensus $150 million, or wherever the number is. And then you kind of said, yeah, that looks reasonable or whatever. So maybe you can just talk about some of the assumptions that you have and why that number is comfortable for you?

Thomas S. McHugh:

Yeah, certainly. Starting call. Yeah. Consensus was about $155 million for 2024. And our comment was, we're comfortable with that. Across the various sell side, there's different assumptions that get to that number, of course, but from a pure numbers perspective, what we have to achieve is, on average, about 1,300 reimbursed patients on therapy during the course of 2024. That's the average. And we've been very consistent that we believe that the average net revenue per patient is about $120,000 per year. So that's the two baseline assumptions to achieve that consensus number. And we think that there's the opportunity to overachieve as well, go above and beyond $155 million if the pace of patient demand accelerates beyond what we're seeing today, if the total number of patients on therapy exceeds those assumptions at various points in time, of course, net pricing could be higher as well.

Marc Goodman:

Well, the number of patients today are what as of the end of January? I think you said 1,200, didn't you?

Thomas S. McHugh:

Yes. What we had reported was 1,200 patients who initiated therapy.

Marc Goodman:

That's not an average on therapy.

Thomas S. McHugh:

That's right, yeah.

Marc Goodman:

Right. So you only need to get to 1,300 on average for the year.

Thomas S. McHugh:

Correct.

Gregory J. Divis:

I think the other point is that we're obviously really pleased with where we are, but we get asked all the time in one on one meetings about our view on consensus and we have a similar comment. We're comfortable with consensus, and we felt it was appropriate just to confirm that as kind of one time so everybody could hear it. But I think we feel really good where we sit today and with a lot of room to grow.

Marc Goodman:

Right. Well, I mean, I was saying when you look at the math, it would have to be pretty disappointing rest of the year for you not to beat that number. You're already at 1,200 patients.

Gregory J. Divis:

Yeah, certainly. Everything we see is, as we always say, up and to the right in terms of continued enrollments.

Marc Goodman:

That's an initial payment. Initial, that's 1,200. So when does it become fully, like, there's no scaling up of pricing and dosing and anything like that, right? So once they start, they're at that average dose right off the bat?

Richard Kim:

Yes. We're assuming on average patients will be on a 7.5 gram dose. That's the nearest equivalent dose to where we see the twice nightly is, which is 7.6 grams. Not all patients get there right away. Some will switch immediately to that equivalent dose, others will start at 4.5 grams, our lowest dose, and tie, trade up.

Marc Goodman:

What does the market research say about the orexin kind of noise and excitement? Does that impact oxybates, you think, down the line?

Gregory J. Divis:

It's a great question, Marc. We'd also sort of rely on a lot of our thought leader feedback that we're receiving as well. There's a lot of excitement. We're also excited. It's always great when new mechanisms potentially can come into marketplace. Obviously, some of the companies have shared some of their data. One of the companies announced that they'll be going to Phase III later on this year. I think we're still learning about what the true product profile is going to be. These orexin agonists look very exciting, but they've also come with different sorts of tolerability or adverse events as well. So these are chronic therapies.

And I think we're also trying to understand what the impact to sort of the nocturnal view will be on these. So I remind myself right now that the most used product has an 80% share, and that's because they're generic with stimulants in this marketplace. Oxybates today are used in less than 10% of the overall narcolepsy marketplace. So we sort of view LUMRYZ as an ideal product to address EDS and cataplexy without disrupting the night time. And we still believe that we'll be in a unique category, even if orexins come into the marketplace as well.

Marc Goodman:

Greg, do you think about bringing an orexin in?

Gregory J. Divis:

Well, as a company that's focused on rare sleep, it behooves us to have a sense of what's going on across all of our fellow companies and what they're working on and sharing with them what we're doing. So it certainly is something we're monitoring and staying close to in terms of what's happening from that standpoint, and certainly something we would, as a company in the space, would have to evaluate if that opportunity presented itself.

Marc Goodman:

I want to talk about what you're working on from a pipeline perspective internally, but before we get there, just how you're thinking about external versus internal, because we're going to break even this year, which means we're going to start to make cash pretty soon, build it up.

Gregory J. Divis:

Yeah, first and foremost is to really execute our core strategy, which is continuing to launch and really realize the promise and potential of LUMRYZ and narcolepsy, execute our lifecycle, which we'll talk about in pediatric IIH and whatnot. But we are at a place where we're building capabilities to understand what's out there in the marketplace. Obviously, rare sleep is a place we want to be deep in and understand all the different things happening in terms of a develop from the development perspective, and be in a position where if opportunities present themselves to add an asset to our portfolio. We're in a position, but recognizing that the most important thing we can do in the near-term is continuing to deliver on the launch and execute our current game plan. That creates the greatest optionality for us to determine where we take the company next. But rare sleep, we want to be deep in anything that would come across our desk outside of that in the near-term would have to pass a pretty high bar.

Marc Goodman:

So if we're bringing in an orexin, it's probably next year, not this year. Let's talk about what you're working on in the pipeline. The pediatric, give us just the work that's been done, the timelines and how much you think that will add, and then IIHs?

Gregory J. Divis:

Yeah. I think the first comment I would make generally about our lifecycle strategy is that when we talk to physicians and we talk to them about LUMRYZ and narcolepsy, it's very quick. We get asked about pediatrics and IIH. So they were obvious, clear next steps for us to pursue from that standpoint, because we heard it directly from prescribers. Pediatric status is we filed our supplemental NDA back in November. We'll have an action date. We have an action date of September 7 of 2024. So that's a Saturday. The FDA won't work on a Saturday, but we would expect a decision either the Friday before, the Monday after. From that standpoint.

Right now, today, that represents, depending on which claims database you look at, at 3% to 5% of the current treated oxybate patient population, we think there's more potential out there beyond that. But I will say that as much as we've heard from patients who are eligible for LUMRYZ today, we hear comparable request and interest from parents who have children who are on an oxybate. So although the pediatric patient population isn't the largest subset, it certainly introduces additional patient population, and it addresses a very significant need in terms of the family, the parents, and the caregivers, who, as we've heard numerous times, that when you have a child who takes an oxybate, it just doesn't disrupt the child, it disrupts the family. So again, we have that well in advance, and we'll look forward to a potential decision and approval later this year.

In terms of IIH, we've spent quite a bit of time really trying to understand that opportunity, even more so as we've watched the twice-nightly advance in their launch over the last couple two plus years, or whatever it's been now. And with over 30,000 uniquely diagnosed IIH patients, another 12,000 or so who are co-diagnosed with IIH and/or narcolepsy, there's a robust patient population that with only one currently FDA approved treatment, with less than 10% penetration of that marketplace, we think there's a lot of opportunity and the thing we hear about IIH is that these patients, different from narcolepsy in that they really physically struggle at times with waking up, with the deep sleep inertia that they suffer from. So the opportunity to give them a full course of therapy and not force them to wake up, that physically is hard for many of these patients, is highly attractive from the clinician community.

So we've advanced that study quite from a planning standpoint quite far, since over the last couple of months, in an accelerated fashion, we would expect to be in the clinic with first patient enrolled and initiated in the second half, and as early as we can in the second half. So we get asked all the time about how long do we think that study will take. We haven't given specific guidance yet, only because we're still doing site feasibility and really assessing enrollment timelines and enrollment target populations by site. But if you look at the two predecessor trials, between the Harmony trial and the Jazz trial, it took between really little more than 12 months to a little under 18 months to complete. So I think that's a reasonable proxy, as we think about it now, recognizing that we haven't completed site feasibility, but we should be initiating that in the second half and be off and running.

Marc Goodman:

Okay, just for completeness, just remind everybody what's still outstanding from a litigation perspective with Jazz? What have we learned? What do we solve outstanding?

Gregory J. Divis:

Yeah. So the most recent event was the patent litigation. So the trial was held a little over a week ago, and the jury trial came back with a verdict just this past Monday, just a week ago. So the bottom line is, in terms of the verdict, it was a split decision. It was determined that we didn't infringe one of the patents, and the jury determined that the other patent that Jazz has is valid. And what the jury awarded was the equivalent of a 0.7% royalty to Jazz. And this is only past damages. What you see in the headlines is a 3.5% royalty, but what the jury determined is that a 3.5% royalty would be applied to approximately 20% of our launch to date revenues. So we refer to it as the equivalent of about a 0.7% royalty. That's where we stand today in terms of that particular piece of litigation.

The next steps to put on the calendar, we don't have the exact date, but the judge will have to make a final ruling on that jury decision, as well as a determination of what, if any, future royalties might apply.

Marc Goodman:

Okay, so that's something we're expecting in the next few months.

Gregory J. Divis:

Yeah, it's probably, I couldn't even give you a time frame, but I'll say hopefully, this calendar year.

Marc Goodman:

Oh, it could be later in the year. Okay, so that's one and then the other.

Gregory J. Divis:

Yes. So the next upcoming event is on April 9. This is where Jazz sued FDA, believing that the approval of LUMRYZ should be vacated. It's not a jury trial. This is strictly API hearing. So probably 2 to 3 hours length, then the judge will decide after that date. We're hoping for a ruling, probably by the time we exit Q2 on that.

Marc Goodman:

2Q, interesting. Okay. And that'll be it?

Gregory J. Divis:

That'll be it as far as those two pieces, right. There are two instances where we've initiated litigation against Jazz. Those hearings are now scheduled for the fourth quarter of 2025.

Marc Goodman:

Okay. Fourth quarter.

Gregory J. Divis:

So pretty far on the future. I'm sure we'll have more questions later on, but we're still in the early phases of those.

Marc Goodman:

This is for you suing jazz for.

Gregory J. Divis:

For suing Jazz for misappropriation at trade secrets as well as antitrust.

Marc Goodman:

Okay. Never a dull moment. Richard, how do you see the oxybate market right now as far as just what's happening with the generics kind of coming in? Is it having any impact on your business at all? Or are they taking a lot of market share? I can't quite figure it out.

Richard Kim:

Yeah, it's a great question, Marc. What we can sort of see is, ah, what the authorized generics have done is predominantly cannibalized, branded Xyrem and have that switch. Clearly there may be some new starts, but it looks like it's predominantly swapping one for the other. And that's really been the main impact in the marketplace thus far.

Marc Goodman:

Yeah, that's what it kind of feels like. Right?

Richard Kim:

That's right.

Marc Goodman:

Yeah. So, Greg, what's kind of -- you talk to people and you finish a meeting and you're like, I don't think they appreciate X or Y in our business. What's still a little bit underappreciated?

Gregory J. Divis:

Well, I think we like to call ourselves a show me story, right. When we share how we view the opportunity, how we view the market. I think we're a bit of a show me story. And I think we've started the trend with our first two quarters of launch that we are delivering or exceeding what folks thought we would be able to do. But I do think that there's probably two things that we tend to address when we talk to investors. The first one is the litigation, and we're coming, at least the litigation initiated by the other company. We're coming to a point in time over the next couple of months when most of that lift will be behind us, right. And there'll be much more clarity. And last Monday's decision was a major step forward from that clarity standpoint in a good way for us.

And then I would say the second piece is just what is the true potential of LUMRYZ in the marketplace? We have a very clear view of what we think multi source generics, what impact they will or won't have in the future. So we have those discussions for sure. So I think for us, and working with folks like yourself, is to continue to print really strong quarters and see you up your future forecast and potential and peak sales down the road, and as we continue to deliver and execute. But I think ultimately those are the two biggest things, is what's the real potential, which we think from our perspective, and all the six quant studies that Richard talked about, that it's $1 billion product opportunity if we can execute it on basically what physicians are reporting to us in surveys of large numbers, and we continue to clear the last couple of remaining litigation matters.

Marc Goodman:

So $1 billion was what you think the Street still not at $1 billion. Where's the Street now you think?

Gregory J. Divis:

The street has its pretty wide range out there, but there are certainly a few people on the sell side who have north of $500 million, up to $700 million, $800 million. I think at a minimum, most are moving at least to the $500 million mark at this point.

Marc Goodman:

So $500 million to $800 million is the range. So the average is somewhere in there. Most people that were closer to $500 million.

Richard Kim:

That's been a consistent upward movement. And to Greg's point, we've always believed we're a show me story. As we continue to put up good numbers, good quarters, the estimates continue to rise appropriately.

Marc Goodman:

And just back on the litigation, I just want to make sure I understand something when the judge comes back and talks about this royalty that the jury kind of ruled on. Can the judge come back and say, this is absolutely crazy, that the jury is making you pay X or Y and up it significantly? I mean, is that even possible?

Richard Kim:

Well, listen, anything is possible, and I want to get too far over my skis and certainly speak for the judge.

Marc Goodman:

You infringed on a patent.

Richard Kim:

But I think the jury to decision certainly has to weigh into that. And 0.7% royalty, perhaps, is a starting point. Listen, we maintain we don't owe royalty at all. We'll continue to fight that fight.

Marc Goodman:

On appeal.

Richard Kim:

But if you can think about it in terms of brackets, the way we think about it right now, it's 0.7% on one end. Perhaps it's 3.5% on the other end. But we have to see what the judge decides at the end of the day.

Marc Goodman:

I just was wondering if there was any case studies where judges just take the jury award and just double, triple it.

Richard Kim:

Not aware of any.

Marc Goodman:

Okay. All right.

Richard Kim:

If you double, 0.7%, it's 1.4%.

Marc Goodman:

I hear you. I mean, even 3% wouldn't be -- I think most people walked away thinking it was 3.5% that day and said, that's fine.

Richard Kim:

It's been a very consistent discussion we've had in all of our meetings here at your conference, which is why we wanted to clarify here on the fireside. It's really a net effective royalty.

Marc Goodman:

Well, it was confusing. I mean, it was in the press release, and you can't blame us for being confused. Thank you for joining us, guys.

Gregory J. Divis:

Appreciate it.

urn:contentItem:68RD-9BY1-JCMN-Y1SG-00000-00Extreme Heat Sparks Wildfires, Health Warnings2023-07-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:49ZLexisNexisExtreme Heat Sparks Wildfires, Health Warnings

The views expressed in any and all content distributed by Newstex and its re-distributors (collectively, the "Newstex Authoritative Content") are solely those of the respective author(s) and not necessarily the views of Newstex or its re-distributors. Stories from such authors are provided "AS IS," with no warranties, and confer no rights. The material and information provided in Newstex Authoritative Content are for general information only and should not, in any respect, be relied on as professional advice. Newstex Authoritative Content is not "read and approved" before it is posted. Accordingly, neither Newstex nor its re-distributors make any claims, promises or guarantees about the accuracy, completeness, or adequacy of the information contained therein or linked to from such content, nor do they take responsibility for any aspect of such content. The Newstex Authoritative Content shall be construed as author-based content and commentary. Accordingly, no warranties or other guarantees are offered as to the quality of the opinions, commentary or anything else appearing in such Newstex Authoritative Content. Newstex and its re-distributors expressly reserve the right to delete stories at its and their sole discretion.

AFP News

July 19th, 2023 ( International Business Times News — Delivered by Newstex )

Extreme heat was forecast across the globe on Wednesday, as wildfires raged and health warnings were in place in parts of Asia, Europe and North America.

Firefighters battled blazes in parts of Greece and the Canary Islands while Spain issued heat alerts and some children in Italy's Sardinia were told to stay away from sports.

From California to China, authorities warned of the health dangers brought by searing temperatures, urging people to drink water and shelter from the sun.

"You can't be in the street, it's horrible," said Lidia Rodriguez, 27, in Madrid.

Temperature records tumbled around the world, with new heat streaks set in China and the United States, and fresh highs in France.

Beijing broke a 23-year-old record with 27 consecutive days of temperatures above 35 degrees Celsius (95 Fahrenheit), forecasters said.

Phoenix broke a similar record, in place for 49 years, with its 19th consecutive day of temperatures of 43.3 Celsius or higher, weather officials said.

In southern France, a record 29.5C was recorded in the Alpine ski resort of Alpe d'Huez, while 40.6C had been recorded for the first time in Verdun in the foothills of the Pyrenees.

In a stark reminder of the effects of global warming, the UN's World Meteorological Agency (WMO) said the trend showed "no signs of decreasing".

"These events will continue to grow in intensity, and the world needs to prepare for more intense heatwaves," John Nairn, a senior extreme heat adviser at the WMO told reporters in Geneva.

Northwest of the Greek capital Athens, columns of smoke loomed over the forest of Dervenohoria, where one of several fires around the capital and beyond was still burning.

Fire spokesman Yannis Artopios called it "a difficult day", with another heatwave on the horizon for Thursday, with expected temperatures of 44C.

A forest fire by the seaside resort of Loutraki, where the mayor said 1,200 children had been evacuated Monday from holiday camps, was still burning.

In the Canary Islands, some 400 firefighters battled a blaze that has ravaged 3,500 hectares of forest and forced 4,000 residents to evacuate, with authorities warning residents to wear face masks outside due to poor air quality.

Temperatures were unforgiving in Italy and in Spain, where three regions were put under hot weather red alerts.

The Italian islands of Sardinia and Sicily have been forecast to possibly surpass a continent-wide record of 48.8C recorded in Sicily in August 2021.

At Lanusei, near Sardinia's eastern coast, a children's summer camp was restricting beach visits to the early morning and forbidding sports, teacher Morgana Cucca told AFP.

In the Sardinian capital of Cagliari, pharmacist Teresa Angioni said patients were complaining of heat-related symptoms.

"They mainly buy magnesium and potassium supplements and ask us to measure their blood pressure, which is often low," Angioni said.

Many throughout Italy sought escape by the sea, including outside Rome, where the midday heat hit 40C.

"Certainly it's better at the beach, you can at least get a little wind from the sea. It's not even possible to remain in the city, too hot," said Virginia Cesario, 30, at the Focene beach near the capital.

Tens of millions of Americans experienced dangerous heat levels on Tuesday.

In the town of San Angelo, Texas, where temperatures were expected to reach 104-108F (40-42C), the National Weather Service said it was "running out of ways to say that it's gonna be hot out there today."

"With temperatures across the area likely topping the 105 mark yet again, we implore you to continue to practice heat safety and try to stay cool," the agency said on Twitter.

And in Arizona, the mercury at Phoenix Sky Harbor Airport again reached 110F on Tuesday, breaking the previous record of 18 consecutive days at or above that temperature, set in 1974.

The heat waves across Europe and the globe are "not one single phenomenon but several acting at the same time", said Robert Vautard, director of France's Pierre-Simon Laplace climate institute.

"But they are all strengthened by one factor: climate change."

The record-setting heat came as US climate envoy John Kerry met with Chinese officials in Beijing, with the world's two largest polluters reviving stalled diplomacy on reducing planet-warming emissions.

Speaking Tuesday at Beijing's Great Hall of the People with China's top diplomat Wang Yi, Kerry called for "global leadership" on climate issues.

Link to the original story.

urn:contentItem:6C41-08W1-DXK2-M3BK-00000-00Will China's $72 Billion EV Tax Breaks Help NIO Stock Recover?2023-06-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:48ZLexisNexisWill China's $72 Billion EV Tax Breaks Help NIO Stock Recover?

Nio Stock price To stimulate sagging electric vehicle (EV) sales, China unveiled a package of tax breaks valued at $72.3 billion (520 billion yuan) over the next four years. This initially caused a spike in shares of Chinese EV maker NIO Inc. (NYSE: NIO) as well as peers Xpeng Inc. (NASDAQ: XPEV) and Li Auto Inc. (NYSE: LI) . However, NIO shares continued to fall lower afterward. NIO shares traded as high as $66.99 in January 2021 but have been on a heart-wrenching decline to $7.00 lows in May 2023.

Shares are edging closer to the apex on their weekly descending triangle, setting up a resolution for a breakout or a breakdown in the coming weeks. TheEV pricing wars have been a race to the bottom as NIO's Q1 2023 margins fell to a stunning low of 5.1%, down from 18.1% in the year-ago period. Chinese NEV Tax Break Plan

Following up on its previous pledge to promote automobile purchases which showed a 7.3% jump in May auto sales, China introduced new tax breaks to purchase new energy vehicles (NEVs). The boost in auto sales resulted from targeted policies bolstering car purchases, including encouraging financial institutions to provide more lending for car purchases.

The new tax package exempts NEV purchase tax from 2024 to 2025 and cuts the purchase tax by 50% from 2026 to 2027. The 2024 to 2025 purchase tax can amount to as much as 30,000 yuan or $4,170 per car.

Cutting the purchase tax in half reduces the exemption value to 15,000 yuan or $2,085 from 2026 to 2027. This extension of the current NEV purchase tax exemption, worth around 115 billion yuan, is scheduled to end after 2023. China classifies NEVs are all-battery EVs (BEVs), plug-in petrol-electric hybrids and hydrogen fuel-cell vehicles (HFCVs.) Raging Forest Fire Losses

On June 9, NIO released its fiscal first-quarter 2023 results for the quarter ending March 2023. NIO reported an EPS loss of ($0.36) which was $0.05 better than analyst expectations. Gross profit fell (88.8%) to $23.6 million YoY. Losses from operations climbed 133.6% YoY ($744.3 million). Net loss climbed 165.9% YoY to ($690.1 million).

The company reported revenues of $1.55 billion, up 7.7% year-over-year (YoY), but missed analyst estimates by ($80 million). Total deliveries in the quarter rose 20.1% to 31,041. Vehicle margin fell to 5.1%, down from 18.1%, and gross margins fell to 1.5% versus 14.6% in the year-ago period due to the EV pricing wars in China. The company ended the quarter with $5.5 billion in cash and short-term investments. Glass Half-Full CEO

NIO CEO William Bin Li stayed optimistic, "On May 24, 2023, NIO launched the All-New ES6, an all-round smart electric SUV and started its deliveries the next day. With exquisite design, high performance, superior comfort, and advanced digital systems, the All-New ES6 has received overwhelmingly positive feedback from our users.

With the volume ramp-up of our new models, including the All-New ES6, our teams are well prepared for a solid growth in vehicle deliveries." For Q2 2023, the company expects sequential vehicle delivery to decline from 23K to 25K. Revenues are expected between $1.27 billion to $1.36 billion, down (15.1%) to (9%) YoY.

NIO analyst ratings and price targets are at MarketBeat.

The definitive beginner's guide to reading stock charts can be found free on Marketbeat.

  Learn how to use the RSI indicator on MarketBeat. Weekly Descending Triangle

The weekly candlestick chart on NIO has been downtrend after peeking at $24.43 in January 2022. Shares continued to make lower highs on bouncing, forming the descending trendline against a flat-bottom trendline around $7.22. The weekly RSI has been rejected at the 50-band since the start of the triangle.

The weekly market structure low (MSL) at $10.75 continues to be a formidable resistance as it has rejected breakout attempts as recently as June 12, 2023. The weekly 20-period exponential moving average (EMA) is flattening at $9.06. The apex point is nearing, so a breakdown or breakout is imminent. Pullback supports are at $8.07, $7.33 triangle flat-bottom trendline, $6.00 and $5.65.

urn:contentItem:68JK-8DX1-DY7R-R54W-00000-00New Climate Change Study Results from Suresh Gyan Vihar University Described (Uncovering the Hydro-meteorological Drivers Responsible for Forest Fires Utilizing Geospatial Techniques)2023-06-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:49ZLexisNexisCLIMATE CHANGENew Climate Change Study Results from Suresh Gyan Vihar University Described (Uncovering the Hydro-meteorological Drivers Responsible for Forest Fires Utilizing Geospatial Techniques)


2023 JUN 26 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- Research findings on Climate Change are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting out of Jaipur, India, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Forest fires have become a growing concern worldwide, with climate change exacerbating their frequency and intensity. In the Simlipal region of India, forest fires are relatively rare; however, in 2021, significant damage occurred in the buffer area's forests."


Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Suresh Gyan Vihar University, "Understanding the driving factors behind these events is essential for developing effective management strategies. This study investigates the impact of hydro-meteorological conditions on forest fire causes in the Simlipal region by analyzing Terra climatic data and geo-statistics for the period of 1984 to 2021. Long-term trends were determined using non-parametric tests on the Google Earth Engine (GEE) cloud computing platform. Our findings reveal that the maximum burned area location has a decreasing trend in Land Surface Temperature (LST), with a small portion (<10%) showing an increasing trend (0.02 degrees C/year) near burned locations. Wind speed is decreasing at a rate of -0.006 m/s/year. The sudden forest fires are caused by the combined effect of increasing LST and decreasing wind speed in some areas (<10% of the region). However, the major factor contributing to forest fires in the entire area is the rising trend of annual potential water deficit and actual evapotranspiration, as well as an increasing trend of minimum temperature. The soil moisture deficit during the summer season, especially between 2012 and 2021, contributed to forest fires in the burned area. The soil moisture deficit during the summer season, particularly from 2012 to 2021, played a significant role in the occurrence of forest fires in the affected area. The study emphasized the need for increased attention to this region in order to preserve biodiversity, which was assessed through an analysis of burned severity mapping in GEE (Google Earth Engine). These findings have important implications for future forest management strategies in the Simlipal region. Climate variability is likely to exacerbate the frequency and intensity of forest fires in the region, necessitating effective management strategies to mitigate their impact. Such strategies could involve improving fire prevention and control measures, such as creating fire breaks and increasing the availability of fire-fighting equipment, as well as enhancing forest monitoring systems to detect potential fires early."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Additionally, efforts to address climate change, proper management of land use practices, and reduce greenhouse gas emissions could help to mitigate the future impacts of forest fires in the Simlipal region and elsewhere."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Uncovering the Hydro-meteorological Drivers Responsible for Forest Fires Utilizing Geospatial Techniques. Theoretical and Applied Climatology, 2023. Theoretical and Applied Climatology can be contacted at: Springer Wien, Sachsenplatz 4-6, PO Box 89, A-1201 Wien, Austria. (Springer - www.springer.com; Theoretical and Applied Climatology - www.springerlink.com/content/0177-798x/)
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Suraj Kumar Singh, Suresh Gyan Vihar University, Center for Sustainable Development, Jaipur 302017, India. Additional authors for this research include Saurabh Kumar Gupta, Shruti Kanga, Gowhar Meraj and Pankaj Kumar.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1007/s00704-023-04497-y. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Keywords for this news article include: Jaipur, India, Asia, Climate Change, Global Warming, Suresh Gyan Vihar University.
Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world. Copyright 2023, NewsRx LLC

urn:contentItem:691C-6431-JCM7-R009-00000-00Climate change doubled chance of weather conditions that led to record Quebec fires, researchers say2023-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:48ZLexisNexisAPg. 010Climate change doubled chance of weather conditions that led to record Quebec fires, researchers sayTAMMY WEBBER Associated Press

Climate change more than doubled the chances of the hot, dry weather that helped fuel the unprecedented wildfire season in eastern Canada that's driven thousands from their homes and blanketed parts of the U.S. with choking smoke, according to an analysis.

What's more, human-caused climate change made the fire season in Quebec — from May through July — 50% more intense than it otherwise would have been and increased the likelihood of similarly severe fire seasons at least sevenfold, researchers said.

"The biggest takeaway is, this is because of us that we have seen so many fires this year,” due to greenhouse gas emissions, said Yan Boulanger, a research scientist in forest ecology for Natural Resources Canada. He was one of 16 researchers who collaborated on the analysis for World Weather Attribution, an initiative that aims to quickly evaluate the role of climate change in the aftermath of extreme weather events.

Canada is in the middle of its worst wildfire season on record, with more than 5,800 fires burning over 59,000 square miles from one end of the country to the other, according the the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre. In Quebec alone, more than 20,000 square miles has burned so far this year — an area 176 times larger than all of last year.

Though the analysis, released Tuesday, looked only at a region of Quebec, hot temperatures and drought conditions also were at a record level in the rest of Canada, “and we know that those fire-prone conditions also are increasing in severity, especially out West,” Boulanger said.

Ongoing wildfires have burned dozens of structures in a resort area of British Columbia and prompted authorities to evacuate about 20,000 people from Yellowknife, the capital of the Northwest Territories.

The analysis estimated the peak intensity of the fire weather by looking at real-world observations in a metric called the Fire Weather Index — which estimates wildfire risk by combining temperature, wind speed, humidity and precipitation — averaged over seven days. The researchers then compared that to a world without climate change using multiple computer simulations and historical weather data, a technique widely accepted in the scientific community. They found that the fire-weather conditions this year were twice as likely.

They also assessed the cumulative effect of the weather conditions from January to July, determining that the duration of those conditions was seven times more likely.

Peter Reich, a forest ecologist who wasn't involved in the analysis, said he was glad researchers didn't try to prove climate change caused the fires, but instead looked at the probability that the conditions that led to this year’s fire season would have occurred with or without climate change.

“To me, the scariest finding is just the magnitude of the greater likelihood of intense fire weather because of climate change,” said Reich, head of the Institute for Global Change Biology at the University of Michigan and a professor at the University of Minnesota. “It’s not just 10% more likely or 20% — there’s a 600%” greater likelihood.

Although the analysis did a good job of assessing extreme fire weather, it didn’t capture how broadly it affected the entire country, especially in the arid West, which would show an even stronger connection to climate change, said Mike Flannigan, a professor for wildland fire at Thompson Rivers University in British Columbia.

“I've never seen such a wide geographical area in Canada on fire at the same time … and fire season is not over yet,” he said.

Reich said the findings likely would apply across the planet because hotter temperatures increase the drying power of the air, and climate change makes fire vulnerability, severity and risk much higher by increasing the flammability of the materials and weather conditions that will produce and carry fire at the same time. “It kind of feeds on itself,” he added.

Canada’s fire season began early, after snow melted quickly and the warmest May-June period in more than 80 years combined with sparse rainfall to dry out vegetation and make it more flammable. Windy conditions also drove the wildfires throughout most of the country.

In Canada, 5% of the population identifies as Indigenous — First Nation, Métis or Inuit — yet researchers say they were disproportionately affected by wildfires because their communities often are isolated and in some of the most fire-prone areas, like the boreal forest.

Scientists say that risks will increase as the planet continues to warm. "That's a very big wake-up call” for communities that need to adapt, Boulanger said.

Flannigan said widespread, hotter fires are “the new reality” and will require new approaches to preventing and battling increasingly dangerous and intense blazes.

"Unfortunately, we're going to see more fire and smoke in the future," he said, explaining that there won't be enough rain to compensate drier fuels, leading to higher-intensity fires that are becoming almost impossible to extinguish.

He added: “We're really in uncharted territory.”

urn:contentItem:6567-BHG1-JCBF-S333-00000-00FIRST EVER NTCA MEETING OUTSIDE NATIONAL CAPITAL HELD AT ARUNACHAL PRADESH2022-04-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:49ZLexisNexisFIRST EVER NTCA MEETING OUTSIDE NATIONAL CAPITAL HELD AT ARUNACHAL PRADESHStates News ServiceNEW DELHI, India

The following information was released by the Government of India:

Arunachal offers a model to emulate with programmes like Hornbill Nest Adoption and Air Gun Surrender Abhiyan: Shri Bhupender Yadav

Within a year of this community and compassion driven programme, Arunachal has witnessed a surrender of over 2,200 hundred Air Guns , I urge all states governments to take up the Airgun surrender Abhiyan : Shri Bhupender Yadav

Union Minister for Environment Forest and Climate change chairs the 20th NTCA in Arunachal Pradesh

Releases Standard Operating Protocol to deal with the reintroduction and supplementation of tigers in wild prepared by NTCA

Forest Fire Audit Protocol for Tiger Reserves released

Technical manual on Management Effectiveness Evaluation (MEE) of Tiger Reserves in India released by NTCA

Posted On: 09 APR 2022 3:24PM by PIB Delhi

The 20th Meeting of National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA) was held in Pakke tiger reserve in Arunachal Pradesh today under the chairmanship of Union Minister for Environment, Forest and Climate Change Shri Bhupender Yadav.

For the first time in history the NTCA meeting happened outside the national capital. In order to get first hand information about reserve,local issues etc. the Union Minister had directed that henceforth these meetings will be held outside Delhi in forest areas or in tiger reserves.

On the occassion minister said that we should promote our tigers reserves across country which has immense flora and fauna while at the same time ensuring the livelihoods of the people dependant on forests.

Minister also pressed on active involvement of locals for conservation and better development of forest area and tiger reserve. He said that we should conduct meeting with all stakeholders including forest officials who deal with different issues, local villagers, experts, students for the same.

On the occasion around 100 air gun were surrendered by the local villagers. Rampant use of Air gun was a problem in north eastern states. Arunachal Pradesh in March 2021, had started the Air Gun Surrender Abhiyaan which has so far yielded great results.

The Minister released standard operating procedure for tiger reintroduction and supplementation in wild , forest fire audit protocol for tiger reserves , technical manual on MEE of Tiger reserves in India prepared by NTCA.

India harbors about 70% of the world's tiger population in wild. The tigers occupy different landscapes in the country. While some landscapes have rich and viable populations in accordance with the habitat and prey-base, there are some habitats that are under occupied for various regions but have potential to support better tiger population. There may be some more habitats where the population of tiger have disappeared.

In this scenario, it sometimes becomes imperative to re-introduce tigers or supplement the existing population. This being a sensitive and technical task, the NTCA has prepared a Standard Operating Protocol (SOP) to deal with the reintroduction and supplementation. The SOP takes into account, the scientific knowledge available on the subject as well as conditions that may be typical to India. To deal with tiger reintroduction and supplementation in the wild in areas where it was historically present but is now being extirpated or found in low densities viz-a-viz the carrying capacity, due to various reasons but welfare factors to foster tiger presence still exists or can be improved with adequate management intervention. Therefore, the NTCA is releasing a SOP titled, 'Tiger Reintroduction and Supplementation in Wild Protocol'.

Foret Fire Audit Protocol for Tiger Reserves

Forest Fires play a crucial role in maintaining the dynamics of forest. Fire can play a vital role in healthy forests, recycling nutrients, helping tree species regenerate, removing invasive weeds and pathogens and maintaining habitat for some wildlife. Occasional fires can keep down the fuel loads that feed larger, more destructive conflagration. However, as populations and demands on forest resources have grown, cycle of fire has spun out of the balance and these uncontrolled and repeated fires at short succession are one of the major causes behind forest degradation and biodiversity loss. Increasing forest fires have now become a global concern. So, in order to help the tiger reserve managers assess their fire preparedness and manage complete life cycle of forest fires, the NTCA has prepared a Forest Fire Audit Protocol for Tiger Reserves and is now being released.

Management Effectiveness Evaluation (MEE) of Tiger Reserves in India

Survival of tigers is dependent on conservation and management efforts and to guage the success of conservation efforts as well as to guide management inputs, it is important to assess the management effectiveness of Tiger Reserves. India is amongst the selected countries in the world that have institutionalized the MEE Process. The globally accepted framework of Management Effectiveness Evaluation (MEE) of tiger reserves has paved way for successfully assessing the tiger conservation efforts in the country. The MEE exercise in tiger reserves was initiated in 2006 and four cycle has been completed. Since then a lot of experience has been gained and need was felt revisit and review the whole process. Accordingly, a committee was constituted by the National Tiger Conservation Authority to revisit and review the MEE criteria for the 5th cycle of MEE exercise starting 2022. The intention was to bring about parity in the analysis of diverse tiger reserves of the country and to guide the evaluators with respect to the assessments to be made in the coming financial year. Based on the suggestions made by the committee, the technical manual on Management Effectiveness Evaluation (MEE) of Tiger Reserves in India is being released by NTCA.

urn:contentItem:68C7-71P1-JBR6-92FS-00000-00Photos Showing Extent of Canada Wildfire Smoke Captured by Astronaut2023-06-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:48ZLexisNexisPhotos Showing Extent of Canada Wildfire Smoke Captured by AstronautJess Thomson

In a picture taken from the ISS, smoke can be seen emerging from the wildfires currently blazing across Nova Scotia.

Smoke billowing out from the vicious wildfires blazing across Nova Scotia on Canada's eastern coast has been snapped from an astronaut aboard the International Space Station (ISS).

Fires are raging across Halifax Regional Municipality, leading to a local state of emergency. Shelburne and Yarmouth counties have also been hit badly.

The ISS photograph, taken by a member of the Expedition 69 crew, shows the fire near Shelburne on May 29. By May 31, this fire had been burning for four days, and had scorched over 75 square miles, making it the largest forest fire in Nova Scotia's history.

Around 50 homes have since been destroyed, with some 2,300 homes evacuated in the Shelburne County area. Some firefighters have even reported that the flames reached over 300 feet tall.

This comes only weeks after alarge number of fires sparked across the provinces of British Columbia and Alberta in the west of the country.

It's thought that these blazes in Nova Scotia grew rapidly due to dry and windy conditions, exacerbated by the fact that the province had an abnormally dry spring, only receiving around half of the usual amount of rainfall across April. The same spate of dry weather and unseasonal heatwaves throughout the spring was also a major driver of the fires in British Columbia and Alberta.

"Everything lined up for a perfect storm, if you will," Tory Rushton, a member of the Nova Scotia House of Assembly, told CBC on Wednesday. "The dry winter, dry spring, perfectly warm breeze and warm weather in the spring has certainly not helped our province at all with this fire season."

Over 800 square miles of Canadian land had burned as of May 31, 13 times the ten-year average for springtime.

Eight illegal burns were found on Monday by conservation officers across Nova Scotia, leading Nova Scotia Premier Tim Houston to urge locals to adhere to the province-wide burn ban.

"Don't be burning right now. No burning in Nova Scotia," Houston said in a Tuesday news conference. "For God's sake, stop burning. Stop flicking your cigarette butts out your car window. Just stop it."

Smoke from the blazes has been blown southwards towards the U.S., as seen in the NASA image, leading to air quality alerts being issued on May 30 in Rhode Island, Massachusetts, and parts of New Jersey and Pennsylvania, with the National Weather Service having issued a Code Orange air quality alert for Philadelphia.

Shaun Hatfield, a municipal councilor in Barrington, told CBC that local firefighters were surprised by the strength and power of the blazes, especially the one near Halifax.

"They've never really seen a fire move with as voracious an appetite as this one," he said. "It seems insatiable. It seems to be spreading faster than any of us imagined."

Temperatures are expected to spike to over 86 F over the rest of the week, giving little respite to firefighters and risking further blazes emerging. Firefighters are arriving from New York and New Hampshire on June 3 to help fight the blazes, according to an update from the Nova Scotia government.

urn:contentItem:691B-5651-JBM5-F503-00000-00CLIMATE CHANGE MADE CANADA FIRES LIKELIER2023-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:49ZLexisNexisLOCALPg. A8CLIMATE CHANGE MADE CANADA FIRES LIKELIERSTUDY TAMMY WEBBER Associated Press

Climate change more than doubled the chances of the hot, dry weather that helped fuel the unprecedented wildfire season in eastern Canada that's driven thousands from their homes and blanketed parts of the U.S. with choking smoke, according to an analysis.

What's more, human-caused climate change made the fire season in Quebec - from May through July - 50% more intense than it otherwise would have been and increased the likelihood of similarly severe fire seasons at least sevenfold, researchers said.

"The biggest takeaway is, this is because of us that we have seen so many fires this year," due to greenhouse gas emissions, said Yan Boulanger, a research scientist in forest ecology for Natural Resources Canada. He was one of 16 researchers who collaborated on the analysis for World Weather Attribution, an initiative that aims to quickly evaluate the role of climate change in the aftermath of extreme weather events.

Canada is in the middle of its worst wildfire season on record, with more than 5,800 fires burning over 59,000 square miles from one end of the country to the other, according the the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre. In Quebec alone, more than 20,000 square miles has burned so far this year - an area 176 times larger than all of last year.

Though the analysis, released Tuesday, looked only at a region of Quebec, hot temperatures and drought conditions also were at a record level in the rest of Canada, "and we know that those fire-prone conditions also are increasing in severity, especially out West," Boulanger said.

Ongoing wildfires have burned dozens of structures in a resort area of British Columbia and prompted authorities to evacuate about 20,000 people from Yellowknife, the capital of the Northwest Territories.

Fire Weather Index

The analysis estimated the peak intensity of the fire weather by looking at real-world observations in a metric called the Fire Weather Index - which estimates wildfire risk by combining temperature, wind speed, humidity and precipitation - averaged over seven days. The researchers then compared that to a world without climate change using multiple computer simulations and historical weather data, a technique widely accepted in the scientific community. They found that the fire-weather conditions this year were twice as likely.

They also assessed the cumulative effect of the weather conditions from January to July, determining that the duration of those conditions was seven times more likely.

Peter Reich, a forest ecologist who wasn't involved in the analysis, said he was glad researchers didn't try to prove climate change caused the fires, but instead looked at the probability that the conditions that led to this year's fire season would have occurred with or without climate change.

"To me, the scariest finding is just the magnitude of the greater likelihood of intense fire weather because of climate change," said Reich, head of the Institute for Global Change Biology at the University of Michigan and a professor at the University of Minnesota. "It's not just 10% more likely or 20% - there's a 600%" greater likelihood.

Broad impacts

Although the analysis did a good job of assessing extreme fire weather, it didn't capture how broadly it affected the entire country, especially in the arid West, which would show an even stronger connection to climate change, said Mike Flannigan, a professor for wildland fire at Thompson Rivers University in British Columbia.

"I've never seen such a wide geographical area in Canada on fire at the same time ... and fire season is not over yet," he said.

Reich said the findings likely would apply across the planet because hotter temperatures increase the drying power of the air, and climate change makes fire vulnerability, severity and risk much higher by increasing the flammability of the materials and weather conditions that will produce and carry fire at the same time. "It kind of feeds on itself," he added.

Canada's fire season began early, after snow melted quickly and the warmest May-June period in more than 80 years combined with sparse rainfall to dry out vegetation and make it more flammable. Windy conditions also drove the wildfires throughout most of the country.

'New reality'

In Canada, 5% of the population identifies as Indigenous - First Nation, Métis or Inuit - yet researchers say they were disproportionately affected by wildfires because their communities often are isolated and in some of the most fire-prone areas, like the boreal forest.

Scientists say that risks will increase as the planet continues to warm. "That's a very big wake-up call" for communities that need to adapt, Boulanger said.

Flannigan said widespread, hotter fires are "the new reality" and will require new approaches to preventing and battling increasingly dangerous and intense blazes.

"Unfortunately, we're going to see more fire and smoke in the future," he said, explaining that there won't be enough rain to compensate drier fuels, leading to higher-intensity fires that are becoming almost impossible to extinguish.

He added: "We're really in uncharted territory."

urn:contentItem:68WN-7VC1-DYTH-G3KD-00000-00FANNING THE FLAMES WILDFIRES EMIT POTENT CLIMATE-WARMING ORGANIC PARTICLES2023-08-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:49ZLexisNexisFANNING THE FLAMES WILDFIRES EMIT POTENT CLIMATE-WARMING ORGANIC PARTICLESStates News ServiceST. LOUIS, MO

The following information was released by Washington University in St. Louis:

By Shawn Ballard August 7, 2023

SHARE

As Canadian wildfire smoke continues to impact large swaths of the United States, resulting in poor air quality and negative health outcomes for millions of Americans, more people than ever are feeling the effects of longer fire seasons and a changing climate. Now, researchers at Washington University in St. Louis have discovered that wildfires may have even bigger climate impacts than previously thought.

In a new study published Aug. 7 in Nature Geoscience, researchers led by Rajan Chakrabarty, the Harold D. Jolley Career Development Associate Professor in the Department of Energy, Environmental and Chemical Engineering at the McKelvey School of Engineering, found that wildfires are causing a much greater warming effect than has been accounted for by climate scientists. The work, which focuses on the role of "dark brown carbon" an abundant but previously unknown class of particles emitted as part of wildfire smoke highlights an urgent need to revise climate models and update approaches for the changing environment.

In this timelapse video, view the NOAA-CHEM Twin Otter sampling forest fire smoke in eastern Oregon from Granite Gulch Fire, during August 2019. (Video: NOAA OMAO)

To conduct a comprehensive analysis of what makes up wildfire smoke plumes, Chakrabarty's team spent 45 days traveling to different wildfire locations in the western United States, where they sampled gaseous smoke and aerosol species and analyzed their chemical and optical properties. This research was conducted as part of the Fire Influence on Regional to Global Environments and Air Quality (FIREX-AQ) field campaign, a joint venture led by the National Aeronatics and Space Administration and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

"The conventional understanding has been that dark plumes of wildfire smoke contain black carbon soot, which absorbs solar radiation, while lighter plumes contain mostly organic carbon that scatters sunlight, meaning it offsets the absorption or warming effect of soot," Chakrabarty said. "Typically, climate models ignore or dismiss organic carbon as insignificant compared to black carbon when it comes to warming, but that is not what field observations reveal.

"This is not a binary picture. Instead, we are looking at an entire continuum where there is strong light absorption by organic carbon, or dark brown carbon, similar to black carbon," he said.

During their sampling of ground and airborne smoke from largescale wildfires, Chakrabarty's team encountered an abnormally strong light absorber in plumes that wasn't black carbon, yet it accounted for more than half of observed total absorption.

Chakrabarty turned to Rohan Mishra, associate professor of mechanical engineering and materials science, to investigate this unknown material and its properties. Arashdeep Thind, who earned a doctorate in materials science and engineering in 2021 while working in Mishra's lab, used a sophisticated electron microscope housed at the Center for Nanophase Materials Sciences, a U.S. Department of Energy user facility at Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) to measure the optical properties of individual particles from the smoke samples Chakrabarty's team collected.

"We knew there was something unusual with this material in its composition, structure and absorption spectrum," Mishra said. "By looking at the local atomic structure of the dark brown particles that are the size of only a few tens of nanometers and simultaneously measuring their optical properties using the electron microscope at ORNL, we were able to decipher that these particles are similar to black carbon. It's likely that they form similarly to soot in the high-temperature flames along the leading edges of wildfires."

Mishra and Chakrabarty found that dark brown carbon absorbs slightly less light than black carbon on a per particle basis, but it is four times more abundant in plumes. This means that stealthy dark brown carbon particles in wildfires probably result in much more climate warming than previously recognized.

They also noted that these particles absorb wavelengths of light from ultraviolet to near infrared, covering the entire visible spectrum. Surprisingly, this potent brown carbon is resistant to sunlight-driven photochemical bleaching that makes light-absorbing organic aerosols lose their absorptivity in the atmosphere.

The team's findings have broad implications. With wildfires predicted to rise globally in the coming decades, the role of dark brown carbon produced in fires will be even more impactful. Chakrabarty and Mishra say this underscores the need to harness multidisciplinary collaboration to revise existing climate models to account for the unexpected effects of brown carbon in wildfire smoke. Without this critical adjustment, they said, there is the risk of underestimating the global warming effects of wildfires, and thus, the urgency of climate change mitigation efforts.

urn:contentItem:68JJ-MX11-JB40-X0K5-00000-00Will Chinaâ€™s $72 Billion EV Tax Breaks Help NIO Stock Recover?2023-06-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:49ZLexisNexisWill Chinaâ€™s $72 Billion EV Tax Breaks Help NIO Stock Recover?

Nio Stock price To stimulate sagging electric vehicle (EV) sales, China unveiled a package of tax breaks valued at $72.3 billion (520 billion yuan) over the next four years. This initially caused a spike in shares of Chinese EV maker as well as peers and . However, NIO shares continued to fall lower afterward. NIO shares traded as high as $66.99 in January 2021 but have been on a heart-wrenching decline to $7.00 lows in May 2023.

Shares are edging closer to the apex on their weekly descending triangle, setting up a resolution for a breakout or a breakdown in the coming weeks. TheEV pricing wars have been a race to the bottom as NIO's Q1 2023 margins fell to a stunning low of 5.1%, down from 18.1% in the year-ago period. Chinese NEV Tax Break Plan

Following up on its previous pledge to promote automobile purchases which showed a 7.3% jump in May auto sales, China introduced new tax breaks to purchase new energy vehicles (NEVs). The boost in auto sales resulted from targeted policies bolstering car purchases, including encouraging financial institutions to provide more lending for car purchases.

The new tax package exempts NEV purchase tax from 2024 to 2025 and cuts the purchase tax by 50% from 2026 to 2027. The 2024 to 2025 purchase tax can amount to as much as 30,000 yuan or $4,170 per car.

Cutting the purchase tax in half reduces the exemption value to 15,000 yuan or $2,085 from 2026 to 2027. This extension of the current NEV purchase tax exemption, worth around 115 billion yuan, is scheduled to end after 2023. China classifies NEVs are all-battery EVs (BEVs), plug-in petrol-electric hybrids and hydrogen fuel-cell vehicles (HFCVs.) Raging Forest Fire Losses

On June 9, NIO released its fiscal first-quarter 2023 results for the quarter ending March 2023. NIO reported an EPS loss of ($0.36) which was $0.05 better than analyst expectations. Gross profit fell (88.8%) to $23.6 million YoY. Losses from operations climbed 133.6% YoY ($744.3 million). Net loss climbed 165.9% YoY to ($690.1 million).

The company reported revenues of $1.55 billion, up 7.7% year-over-year (YoY), but missed analyst estimates by ($80 million). Total deliveries in the quarter rose 20.1% to 31,041. Vehicle margin fell to 5.1%, down from 18.1%, and gross margins fell to 1.5% versus 14.6% in the year-ago period due to the EV pricing wars in China. The company ended the quarter with $5.5 billion in cash and short-term investments. Glass Half-Full CEO

NIO CEO William Bin Li stayed optimistic, On May 24, 2023, NIO launched the All-New ES6, an all-round smart electric SUV and started its deliveries the next day. With exquisite design, high performance, superior comfort, and advanced digital systems, the All-New ES6 has received overwhelmingly positive feedback from our users.

With the volume ramp-up of our new models, including the All-New ES6, our teams are well prepared for a solid growth in vehicle deliveries. For Q2 2023, the company expects sequential vehicle delivery to decline from 23K to 25K. Revenues are expected between $1.27 billion to $1.36 billion, down (15.1%) to (9%) YoY.
